Dear Amanda Waidelich:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon Mavis, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Title & (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Section supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
Description perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
1

rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On multiple occasions, a staff has transported two youth and
stopped at stores to make personal purchases, leaving the youth
inside the vehicle unsupervised for several minutes.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/28/24.
Youth A reported Staff 2 takes him and Youth B to church on
Sundays. Youth A reported sometimes Staff 2 needs to get gas,
and she will leave them in the car while she is getting gas inside
the gas station. Youth A reported one time, Staff 2 took them to a
BBQ place, and she went inside the restaurant to get food for
herself. Youth A reported Staff 2 left them in the car in the parking
lot while the car was running for approximately 3-4 songs on the
radio before she returned with her food. Youth A reported he
wasn’t sure if the car was locked at the time or not. Youth A
reported he always sits in the front passenger seat of the car and
Youth B sits in the back seat.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/28/24.
Youth B reported Staff 2 takes him and Youth A to church on
Sundays. Youth B reported there have been 1-2 times where Staff
2 has stopped for gas and left him and Youth A in the car alone
while she has gone inside the gas station to pay for gas. Youth B
reported one time in May 2024, Staff 2 stopped to get herself food
from a BBQ place. Youth B reported he and Youth A were left in
the car for approximately 15-20 minutes alone while Staff 2 was
inside getting her food. Youth B reported he thought the car was
off, and the doors were locked, but wasn’t sure.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/28/24.
Staff 1 reported he took Youth A fishing and they stopped at the
gas station to pick up bait. Staff 1 reported Youth A asked if he
could stay in the car while Staff 1 went in the gas station, and Staff
1 replied no. Staff 1 reported Youth A explained Staff 2 lets him
and Youth B stay in the car alone when she goes to the gas
station or gets food for herself, so he thought it was allowed.
Youth A told Staff 1 these incidents occur on Sundays but did not
provide specific dates.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 7/26/24. Staff 2 reported
she has never gone inside a gas station to pay for gas when she
has Youth A or Youth B with her. Staff 2 reported she has only
ever paid for gas at the pump, and she is right outside of the car
2

watching them while she is getting gas. Staff 2 reported one time
on the way home from church, she stopped to get BBQ from an
independent outdoor vendor. Staff 2 reported she was
approximately 5 feet away from the vehicle where Youth A and
Youth B were, and she was only outside of the vehicle for a few
minutes before coming back with her food. Staff 2 reported the
windows of the vehicle were down, she had the keys with her, and
the vehicle was not running. Staff 2 reported shortly after this date,
the topic of transportation and vehicle usage was being discussed
at a team meeting. Staff 2 reported she asked for clarification
during the meeting as to whether she was able to step out of the
car and go 5 feet away to do something while the youth were in
the car. Staff 2 reported she was told no at the meeting, so she
didn’t do it again after she received clarification. Staff 2 reported
Youth A has a safety plan for transportation and outings based on
his behaviors. Staff 2 reported Youth A must ride in the front seat
of the vehicle, must be a certain distance away from other youth,
and cannot be left alone with any youth. Staff 2 reported she
values her job and youth safety, so she would never jeopardize
that.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
Youth A’s safety plan dated 11/14/23 notes Youth A’s is
prone to inappropriate conversations about sexual matters
and/or gestures towards other youth. Proactive safety
strategies include:
o Staff will always keep Youth A in line of sight when
he is in the community.
o Youth A must remain in staff’s line of sight and an
arm’s length away from other youth while in the
community.
o Staff will ensure Youth A is sitting next to staff, and
not next to other youth when in a vehicle.
• Email from Therapist dated 7/2/24 noting youth safety plans
are discussed during staff meetings and documented in
team meeting notes. Therapist notes there have been
multiple discussions during team meetings about
supervision of youth and following youth safety plans;
especially for youth with highly inappropriate sexual
behaviors like Youth A.
• Email from Project Coordinator dated 7/8/24 noting Youth
A’s safety plan was discussed at team meetings on
1/10/24, 1/24/24, 3/6/24, 4/17/24, and 6/11/24. Email notes
Staff 2 did not attend those meetings, but safety plan
3

information was documented in meeting minutes, which are
sent to all staff.

Staff 2 on 1/30/24, 2/1/24, 2/5/24, 2/6/24, 2/8/24, 2/10/24-

5/18/24, -5/21/24, 5/23/24, and 5/27/24-5/30/24.
• Incident reports for Youth A and Youth B dated 6/16/24 and
completed by Staff 1 are consistent with Staff 1’s interview.
• DART Outing request forms note Staff 2 took Youth A and
Youth B to church on 3/10/24, 3/24/24, and 4/7/24.
• Resident Supervision Guidelines Policy notes if youth are in
the community, staff are to position themselves to be able
to observe and hear youth interactions, and to physically
intervene if necessary to provide safety. Safety plans are to
be reviewed and signed by staff prior to every shift to
account for adjustments in plans.
• Staff 2 does not have any disciplinary records in her
employee file. Staff 2 was trained on the supervision
guidelines during orientation in September 2023. These
have also been discussed during staff meetings and sent
out in team meeting minutes multiple times.
Analysis This violation is established as per interviews conducted and
documentation reviewed, Staff 2 did not provide supervision or
follow Youth A’s safety plan as required.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
Special Investigation 2024C0000820SI dated 10/4/23, CAP dated 11/28/23.

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
